clinical_study.brief_title: Project ACCEPT: Engaging Newly Diagnosed HIV+ Youth in Care
clinical_study.official_title: Project ACCEPT: Engaging Newly Diagnosed HIV+ Youth in Care

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

primary_outcome.measure: Examine the efficacy of Project ACCEPT compared with an attention-controlled health education comparison intervention
primary_outcome.description: Conduct a randomized controlled trial to examine the efficacy of Project ACCEPT compared with an attention-controlled health education comparison intervention (HEALTH). The goals of the intervention are to improve engagement in care, decrease psychosocial barriers to care, and decrease sexual risk for youth newly diagnosed with HIV.

secondary_outcome.measure: Explore the relationship between HIV biomarkers and participant's level of engagement in care
secondary_outcome.description: Explore the relationship between HIV biomarkers (i.e., CD4 and viral load) and participant's level of engagement in care.

clinical_study.condition: HIV Positive Youth That Are Newly Engaged in Care

arm_group.description: Participants randomized to the intervention (Project ACCEPT) arm.
Participants randomized to the comparison (HEALTH) arm.

intervention.description: The intervention, Project ACCEPT, combines weekly individual and group sessions that address a range of issues that impact engagement in care for youth living with HIV, including stigma, disclosure, health relationships, substance use, and future life plans.
intervention.other_name: Adolescents Coping, Connecting, Empowering and Protecting Together

intervention.description: The comparison condition, HEALTH, matches Project ACCEPT in number of sessions and duration. The weekly sessions will cover information on alcohol, drugs, HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases (STDs) to meet the ethical responsibility to provide risk reduction information to youth assigned.

facility.name: University of Miami School of Medicine
Stroger Hospital and the CORE Center
